Only buy it on special, and only play it if you've got nothing else. It's not the worst game ever made, but it's just "OK" and I played it in maybe 30 min to 1 hour sessions due to finding it tedious.

An absolute masterpiece. I am late to the Metro franchise. I remember trying the first one years ago, it never clicking with me, and never revisiting it. Recently I bought the Redux games (2033 and Last Light remastered, essentially) and was blown away. Not only was the game play compelling, but the games held up pretty well. I enjoyed both of them. As good as the first two are, this third one is a compelling and beautiful game. They went for a more open-world feel, and built a really immersive and compelling world and story. I was drawn into the world of this game in ways that are rare. Visually beautiful, with a strong narrative, and fun combat. Just really an amazing game that I wish I had played earlier. One of the best single player games in existence.

I was honestly kind of blown away. The Redux version of this game holds up very well against modern titles to this day. The storytelling is great. The A4 Engine is a beast. I'll be honest and say it took me a while to actually get into the game, but once I did I was hooked. My only complaint would be the dream sequences, but I hate those in games in general. Definitely worth a play through, especially if you've tried it before and just couldn't get into it.

First to be critical: a flawed, somewhat outdated looking game (in terms of the models and animations). I found quite a few bugs as well, with heads turning around 180 degrees, falling through the floor or clipping through walls a few times, or things not activating. The game crashed on me numerous times, despite high end hardware, and takes ages to build its shaders, causing it to be laggy the first minute or so of play. The skills, besides the combat based ones, mostly don't serve  purpose and you can get away with not upgrading any of them if you wanted to. You feel a bit overpowered as well, by the end of the game if you upgraded your armour and combat abilities and kitted your gun with the right mods, you can kill hundreds of enemies. The world feels empty, there isn't much to do outside the main missions. It's supposed to be a big crowded city but it feels basically abandoned. Small town on a Sunday vibes. All that said, still play it! It's fun to be RoboCop. For all its flaws, the game still somehow manages to be fun to play. This isn't the greatest game ever, but it is a fun one, especially if you're more on the casual side. I found myself being sad that it's over at the end, and would probably play any follow up entries (hopefully a bit more polished).

I was incredibly bored by the opening bits of the game. I found the soviet thirst a bit weird, but only found out about the pro-Russian / anti-Ukrainian / FSB can have your data in the terms and conditions stuff later. If I had known the latter I would never have bought it to begin with, but it's not that that made me stop playing. Right off the bat it's clearly VERY inspired by Bioshock, and reminded me a lot of Infinite. Except with terrible voice acting, a world where everyone calls you Comrade, and clunky pacing. For reference, I liked the Bioshock and Wolfenstein games. I saw some of the reviews comparing this to those, which is mainly why I bought it. It does remind me of those, but not in a good way. It's like Wolfenstein, but unaware of its irony, and Bioshock, but without everything that makes it good. Just my opinion. If you don't mind the FSB having your data, playing a game that possibly funds the war in Ukraine, and playing a game inferior to all its inspiration, then go ahead. I'd rather just play Bioshock again, personally.

Feels clunky and not very fun. The opening sequence is alright, and the graphics are quite good. The story is meh. It's definitely not as good a game as Deadspace was. The enemies are kinda predictable: if you walk near a vent or crack in the wall, after a while you just know something is going to pop out. The combat is boring as hell and very poorly implemented. Fighting multiple enemies is a mess, switching weapon a pain in the arse, and the dodge mechanic doesn't feel like it works right. Weapons aren't that fun to use. Most of the game involves throwing enemies with the GRP glove or bashing them with a stick. There is a crazy ramp up in difficulty during and after the platform sequence (you'll know it when you reach it), and some really poor choices in auto save points, causing you to have to re-purchase the same upgrades and sell the same loots dozens of times in some cases just to die in a fight and have to do it again. Death scenes and other animations are a bit too long and can get annoying real quick. Manual saves don't work as you'd expect them to, but rather just serve as alternative checkpoint saves, so serve almost no purpose (I didn't load a manual save other than the test how it works). It's mostly so you can create your own "chapters" to replay later if you want, but the game actually has very little replayability since there's no real variation in anything. You'll be stuck seeing the same cut-scenes, using the same weapons, and using the same fighting strategies. All-in-all a disappointing game, given the beautiful graphics and environments the artists created. You can see a lot of love, blood, sweat, and tears went into the game, and it's a real shame it just didn't come together into something really amazing. I'd still give it a 6 / 10. But there are definitely more engaging games to play.

I tried very hard to like this game. I returned to it an hour here and an hour there, but I could never manage more than an hour at a time. I wasn't expecting anything in particular, but I was disappointed with what I got. Battles stretch on forever; tedious affairs where you roll and jump around while being interrupted the whole time by new captains giving you speeches about how cool they are. Get ready to die often, especially at the beginning when you haven't levelled and you don't know the game, mostly because everything is poorly explained. The game is basically Assassin's Creed set in Mordor, which should be fun, except it just isn't for some reason. Enemies respawn too quickly and too often making battles dull, areas you clean out don't stay clean making the accomplishment feel pointless. There's no real penalty for dying except the enemies get tougher. It gets better as you upgrade your character, but frankly I just didn't care anymore. The game is boring, and that's the deadliest videogame sin. 6/10.

Review: The good: good storytelling, unique concept, nice soundtrack, makes you think about choices and the effect they have in real life. The bad: overly dramatic voice acting (especially from the lead character), hours of weepy teenage melodrama, some sections go on too long, the little choices don't matter, feels too cinematic for too long at times with many minutes of not interacting with the game at all. Overall Life is Strange is a good, if overrated, game. It has glaring faults, especially in the final episode, and I didn't quite get the emotional kick from it many others did. I found the characters incredibly whiney at times and the voice acting on the lead character to be overly emotional on everything. *In a shaky whispery voice choking up* "yes... I'm, I'm going to take a high fibre dump now... then eat.. ba ba bacon and eggs". I played the episodes all at once in a row, maybe this wouldn't have come across so annoying if I had played it as it was released originally. Some parts had me going, "okay, I get it, it's all very weepy and sad, call a whambulance, can I play the game again now please?" I give the game 6/10. Sadly, what I found was pretty much a hack and slash action RPG with, sure, lots of in game stuff you can read about the world, but the actual gameplay involves very little that isn't simply bashing through armies of enemies Diablo style. This is an okay game, if I could give it a neutral instead of yes or no I'd give it that instead. It's glitchy and on my i7 Windows 10 machine with 16GB RAM crashed several times even with affinity set to 1. Several of the quests bugged out and at times textures disappeared too. A lot of the battle sequences are overly long, yet not all that challenging, patricularly the final battle and the Fade part of the game. I had to force myself to continue several times because I simply got bored with clicking enemies to death and pausing the game a million times to micro manage each character. Sometimes the characters just stand there and get bashed in the head even though you give them orders. There is nothing original or interesting about the plot or game mechanics, it's essentially Baldur's Gate 2 with more fighting and bugs. I honestly don't know what the fuss is about, and in my books this game falls far short from something like Ultima 7 (which I still consider the king of RPG's) or even Skyrim. 5 / 10.

When I first started playing Mass Effect 2 I hated it. I had just finished the first game and the changes were jarring: levelling works differently, all the controls have been overhauled, and I found the first hour of the game pretty dull. I'm not sure why I stuck with the game, but I did, and man am I glad. Turns out Mass Effect 2, while weaker in many areas than the first one, is a great game. Yes, its RPG elements are dumbed down, yes there is a greater focus on FPS elements, and yes the opening chapter is a bit lame, but it pulls everything together beautifully in the end and makes for a great, entertaining, solid entry into the franchise. If you're like me, and you loved the first game, but after an hour of playing you still don't feel like the second one is for you: stick with it. It's worth it. And you will be rewarded for your patience.

I'm part of the small minority that don't think this game is the best in the series. In fact, I don't even think it should be called Assassin's Creed. Black Flag feels like Ubisoft started to create a pirate game, and then halfway through decided that it should be an Assassin's Creed game instead, so they tacked on a few Templar related elements. I've played Asssassin's Creed 1, 2, Brotherhood, Revalations, and 3 before this one. So I am familiar with the lore of the game and what I enjoyed in the series. For me the wheels came off with the terrible protagonist Conor in 3. Assassin's Creed 3 and 4 both feel disjointed to me, and disconnected from the Assassin roots. Somehow the games have become less and less about finding out about the history of the Assassin's and their struggle with the Templars, and more about individual characters that just fall into the organization by chance. The game looks fine, the naval warfare from 3 is back and has been expanded upon greatly - so much so that it makes out a giant chunk of the game so if you didn't enjoy that aspect give this a skip - and combat works well enough, but for me this game is just missing something. Like the core of the game somehow went lost in translation. I don't much care for Conor or Edward, and the stealth element has been almost completely removed from this game as well as (to a lesser extent) its predecessor. In many cases you will be faced with scenario where stealth either isn't possible, or you don't have time to deal with it. The game encourages full frontal attacks in which you endlessly counter attack until heaps of bodies surround you. Perhaps if this was a completely separate game with a different story line I could have enjoyed it, but as an Assasin's Creed game I have to say that I'm disappointed, especially given the extremely hyperbolic reviews I've read. 6/10.

Review: I am a fan of the TV series. I have to honestly say that I didn't think this game was as great as many other people did. Regardless I recommend the game to fans of South Park as there are many throwbacks to episodes and some fun to be had. I can't say that the game felt unfinished or rushed at all and only experienced one bug. Graphics and audio is exactly the same as the TV show. It is labeled an RPG but it feels more like an adventure game to me with RPG elements added on. Think a dumbed down version of something like Day of the Tentacle where you can also upgrade your character. Worth a play for fans of the TV show, or if you're just curious, but if you are easily offended then you should probably stay clear. 7/10.

I only mention this because, if anything, I had a slightly negative bias against this game; I was expecting it to suck, and boy was I wrong. Tomb Raider properly reboots the franchise. It is a larger than life adventure filled with some fun environments to explore and a lot of action packed sequences. The game was clearly built for console, and this comes across in the number of qte's that appear throughout, but if you can stomach that I can wholeheartedly recommend Tomb Raider as a very entertaining experience in the same vein as the Uncharted series. Graphics are surprisingly good, and the voice acting reasonably solid. I'd estimate the average person would get 10-15 hours of play time. 8 / 10.

PSA: DO NOT PICK MASTER DIFFICULTY, AS A NEWCOMER, IT IS A MYTH CREATED BY THE FANBASE I used to hate this game immensely, as the enemies were insanely overpowered and caused me to constantly load quicksaves. Apparently, this is due to the fact I was playing on Master difficulty. People like to spread a misconception that Master difficulty is the correct first time difficulty, saying that enemies are easier to kill, there are less glitches, and that it is tradition. What master difficulty actually does is make the game harder, just like it is supposed to. The game is great, the story, characters, graphical design, atmosphere: all great. However, putting the game on Master difficulty in the early game will ruin the game, so just please listen to me, and do not listen to anybody that tells you to play on Master. Early on, you have horrible weapons, no gear, and limited resources. An experienced player will be able to go through the first part of the game on Master, but that is because they know how to play the game. A newcomer should play on normal so they can learn the game mechanics, and once they get better gear and are confident, they should raise the difficulty to Master.

I would recommend this for full price, but if the full price is a bit too much, on sale this game is a 100% steal. It goes for 10 dollars on sale, and is definitely worth more than 10 dollars.

Review: A lot of old classics fail to stand the test of time. They are clunky, boring, uninteresting, and look like crap. Half Life is not one of those games. The visual style is great for what it is, the gameplay is fun and complex, and it has a very lengthy story. If you have the worst of the worst pc specs and can't even run potato games, I would absolutely recommend this at full price. Otherwise, on sale it is a must buy for the price.
